articles.title: UN Meeting Seeks to Embed Human Rights in New Economic Indicators
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              The artwork "Non Violence" by artist Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd before the start of the United Nations Future Summit in New York, September 21, 2024.
                    © 2024 Michael Kappeler/picture-alliance/dpa/AP Photo
          
    


  
A country’s gross domestic product (GDP), which measures total economic output, is central to how governments assess their economies. But this figure, when looked at in isolation, which is most often the case, incentivizes economic systems that value aggregate productivity, without reflecting environmental degradation, inequality or human rights.A new 14-member high-level expert group, appointed by the United Nations secretary general, is working to change this. Following a commitment in the UN’s Pact for the Future, they have been mandated to develop measures of progress that complement or go beyond GDP as a metric, which they are expected to deliver to the UN General Assembly in 2026. This will then lead to a state-led process to adopt new economic indicators based on the group’s findings.This week, to help shape and inform the direction of this new group, the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and other UN agencies convened a meeting, co-sponsored by Chile, Honduras, Mexico, and Spain, to ensure that human rights are imbedded in these new metrics. They highlighted their transformative potential to reshape economies from ones that champion unchecked economic productivity to those that prioritize people and the planet.Participants proposed including indicators that would help center human rights at the heart of the new metrics, including by measuring:Economic inequality: such as income and wealth distribution, and profits versus wagesPublic social spending: such as on healthcare, education, and social securityEnvironment impact: reflecting the environmental and climate costs of economic activity, as well as the economic value of natural assets  Gender equality: recognizing and valuing unpaid care work, predominantly performed by womenLabour rights: for example, the discrepancy between minimum and living wage, unemployment rates, and working conditionsDemocratic control: public participation in economic decision-makingGovernance: the capacity and accountability of state institutions, which research has linked both to democracy and economic performanceExtraterritorial impact: the extent to which economic policies have harmful impacts on other countries’ economiesAs the Deputy High Commissioner for Human Rights Nada Al-Nashif noted in opening the conference, "'Beyond GDP' is not just about improving growth metrics—it’s about fundamentally rethinking our economic systems." Measuring economic progress by taking into account what really matters for people can help build healthier and fairer human rights economies.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image The artwork "Non Violence" by artist Carl Fredrik Reuterswärd before the start of the United Nations Future Summit in New York, September 21, 2024. © 2024 Michael Kappeler/picture-alliance/dpa/AP Photo

A country’s gross domestic product (GDP), which measures total economic output, is central to how governments assess their economies. But this figure, when looked at in isolation, which is most often the case, incentivizes economic systems that value aggregate productivity, without reflecting environmental degradation, inequality or human rights.

A new 14-member high-level expert group, appointed by the United Nations secretary general, is working to change this. Following a commitment in the UN’s Pact for the Future, they have been mandated to develop measures of progress that complement or go beyond GDP as a metric, which they are expected to deliver to the UN General Assembly in 2026. This will then lead to a state-led process to adopt new economic indicators based on the group’s findings.

This week, to help shape and inform the direction of this new group, the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and other UN agencies convened a meeting, co-sponsored by Chile, Honduras, Mexico, and Spain, to ensure that human rights are imbedded in these new metrics. They highlighted their transformative potential to reshape economies from ones that champion unchecked economic productivity to those that prioritize people and the planet.

Participants proposed including indicators that would help center human rights at the heart of the new metrics, including by measuring:

Economic inequality : such as income and wealth distribution, and profits versus wages

: such as income and wealth distribution, and profits versus wages Public social spending : such as on healthcare, education, and social security

: such as on healthcare, education, and social security Environment impact : reflecting the environmental and climate costs of economic activity, as well as the economic value of natural assets

: reflecting the environmental and climate costs of economic activity, as well as the economic value of natural assets Gender equality : recognizing and valuing unpaid care work, predominantly performed by women

: recognizing and valuing unpaid care work, predominantly performed by women Labour rights : for example, the discrepancy between minimum and living wage, unemployment rates, and working conditions

: for example, the discrepancy between minimum and living wage, unemployment rates, and working conditions Democratic control: public participation in economic decision-making

public participation in economic decision-making Governance : the capacity and accountability of state institutions, which research has linked both to democracy and economic performance

: the capacity and accountability of state institutions, which research has linked both to democracy and economic performance Extraterritorial impact: the extent to which economic policies have harmful impacts on other countries’ economies

As the Deputy High Commissioner for Human Rights Nada Al-Nashif noted in opening the conference, "'Beyond GDP' is not just about improving growth metrics—it’s about fundamentally rethinking our economic systems." Measuring economic progress by taking into account what really matters for people can help build healthier and fairer human rights economies.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant UN initiative to develop new economic indicators that embed human rights and environmental considerations beyond traditional GDP metrics. This effort aims to reshape global economic systems to prioritize people and the planet, reflecting broad societal benefits and meaningful progress toward fairer economies. The story is focused, detailed, and highlights a transformative policy development with potential large-scale impact.
articles.personality_title: UN experts work to create new economic measures that include human rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Countries usually use a number called Gross Domestic Product (GDP) to see how well their economies are doing. GDP counts all the goods and services a country makes. But it doesn’t show important things like how fair the economy is, if people’s rights are respected, or if the environment is harmed.

**What happened** – The United Nations (UN) set up a group of 14 experts to find better ways to measure progress beyond GDP. They will present their ideas to the UN General Assembly in 2026. This week, the UN held a meeting with countries including Chile, Honduras, Mexico, and Spain to discuss how to include human rights in these new economic measures.

**Impact** – This is important because it could change how countries decide what is good economic progress. Instead of just looking at money made, the new measurements would also show if wealth is shared fairly, if governments spend enough on health and education, if the environment is protected, and if workers’ rights are respected. It would also look at gender equality and how much people can take part in economic decisions.

**What’s next step** – The expert group will keep working on these new ways to measure progress and share their final report in 2026. After that, countries will decide if they want to use these new measures to guide their policies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN is creating new economic indicators that include human rights and environmental health to better show true progress in countries.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les experts de l’ONU travaillent à de nouveaux indicateurs économiques intégrant les droits humains
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les pays utilisent généralement un chiffre appelé produit intérieur brut (PIB) pour mesurer la santé de leur économie. Le PIB compte tous les biens et services produits. Mais il ne montre pas des choses importantes comme l’équité, le respect des droits humains ou la protection de l’environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’Organisation des Nations Unies (ONU) a créé un groupe de 14 experts pour trouver de meilleures façons de mesurer le progrès, au-delà du PIB. Ils présenteront leurs idées à l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU en 2026. Cette semaine, l’ONU a organisé une réunion avec des pays comme le Chili, le Honduras, le Mexique et l’Espagne pour discuter de l’intégration des droits humains dans ces nouveaux indicateurs.

**Impact** – Cela est important car cela pourrait changer la façon dont les pays jugent leur progrès économique. Au lieu de ne regarder que l’argent gagné, les nouveaux indicateurs montreraient aussi si la richesse est bien partagée, si les gouvernements dépensent assez pour la santé et l’éducation, si l’environnement est protégé et si les droits des travailleurs sont respectés. Ils prendraient aussi en compte l’égalité des sexes et la participation des citoyens aux décisions économiques.

**Prochaine étape** – Le groupe d’experts continuera à travailler sur ces nouvelles mesures et présentera son rapport final en 2026. Ensuite, les pays décideront s’ils veulent utiliser ces indicateurs pour guider leurs politiques.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – L’ONU élabore de nouveaux indicateurs économiques qui intègrent les droits humains et la santé de l’environnement pour mieux refléter le vrai progrès des pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Expertos de la ONU trabajan en nuevos indicadores económicos que incluyen derechos humanos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los países suelen usar un número llamado Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) para medir cómo está su economía. El PIB cuenta todos los bienes y servicios que un país produce. Pero no muestra cosas importantes como la justicia, el respeto a los derechos humanos o la protección del medio ambiente.

**Qué pasó** – Las Naciones Unidas (ONU) crearon un grupo de 14 expertos para encontrar mejores formas de medir el progreso más allá del PIB. Presentarán sus ideas a la Asamblea General de la ONU en 2026. Esta semana, la ONU organizó una reunión con países como Chile, Honduras, México y España para hablar de cómo incluir los derechos humanos en estas nuevas medidas económicas.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque podría cambiar la forma en que los países deciden qué es un buen progreso económico. En vez de mirar solo el dinero que se gana, las nuevas medidas mostrarían si la riqueza se distribuye justamente, si los gobiernos gastan suficiente en salud y educación, si se protege el medio ambiente y si se respetan los derechos de los trabajadores. También tomarían en cuenta la igualdad de género y la participación pública en decisiones económicas.

**Próximo paso** – El grupo de expertos seguirá trabajando en estas nuevas formas de medir el progreso y presentará su informe final en 2026. Después, los países decidirán si quieren usar estas nuevas medidas para guiar sus políticas.

**Resumen en una frase** – La ONU está creando nuevos indicadores económicos que incluyen derechos humanos y salud ambiental para mostrar mejor el progreso real de los países.

These mandates provide impartial information and assessments that are vital for countering the dangerous spread of disinformation, amplify the voices of victims, such as Sudanese women and girls suffering sexual and gender-based violence, and provide an avenue for human rights defenders facing repression at home, such as in Russia, to engage with the international community.States also worked together to bridge regional divides on addressing systemic racism and providing reparations for the lasting impacts of enslavement and other colonial atrocities. articles.content:
Click to expand Image Palais des Nations in Geneva, Switzerland, June 16, 2025. © 2025 Lian Yi/Xinhua via Getty Images

The latest session of the United Nations Human Rights Council, which concluded last week, offers a glimmer of hope in what are dark times for human rights around the world.

Amidst talk of the erosion of international rule of law and decreasing government willingness to promote human rights abroad and fund rights institutions, countries from across regions acted with civil society groups to defend and protect rights in the world’s trouble spots and on key global issues.

Responding to calls from Afghan and international organizations and UN rights experts, the Council decided by consensus to establish a new independent evidence-gathering body to investigate past and ongoing rights abuses in Afghanistan. The decision puts the Taliban and others responsible for serious crimes in Afghanistan, including the repression of women and girls, on notice that they may someday face justice. Led by the European Union and with support from countries like South Africa and Chile, the initiative also demonstrated commitment to accountability for egregious international crimes, explicitly condemning threats and attacks against the International Criminal Court.

The Council also renewed important UN monitoring and investigation mandates on Russia, Sri Lanka, Sudan and Cambodia, ensuring that much-needed independent international oversight continues on these situations. These mandates provide impartial information and assessments that are vital for countering the dangerous spread of disinformation, amplify the voices of victims, such as Sudanese women and girls suffering sexual and gender-based violence, and provide an avenue for human rights defenders facing repression at home, such as in Russia, to engage with the international community.

States also worked together to bridge regional divides on addressing systemic racism and providing reparations for the lasting impacts of enslavement and other colonial atrocities. For the first time since 2019, the Council adopted by consensus an African group-led resolution on racism. While disagreements remain and real action on reparations is still lacking, as highlighted in Ghana’s joint statement, this is a significant step forward, overcoming deep divisions between regional groups.

Crucial issues of economic inequalities and climate change, impacting rights across the world, particularly in developing countries, were also under discussion. Despite differing positions, the Council managed to adopt by consensus imperfect but significant resolutions on economic, social and cultural rights and inequalities and on sea-level rise.

As some governments seek to lower the bar on human rights and question the value of the multilateral system, these Human Rights Council outcomes show that when states come together with civil society they have the power to make a difference.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the UN Human Rights Council's significant actions to strengthen protections globally, including establishing an independent body to investigate abuses in Afghanistan, renewing mandates for monitoring rights violations in multiple countries, and adopting resolutions on systemic racism and economic inequalities. These actions represent a meaningful, broad, and substantive commitment to human rights accountability and international cooperation, offering hope and tangible progress in a challenging global context.
articles.personality_title: UN Human Rights Council takes strong steps to protect rights worldwide
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations Human Rights Council meets regularly to address serious problems related to human rights around the world. Recently, there have been concerns about fewer countries supporting these rights and less funding for important human rights work.

**What happened** – In its latest meeting, the Council agreed to create a new independent group to collect evidence about human rights abuses in Afghanistan. This group will look into crimes committed by the Taliban, especially against women and girls. The Council also renewed monitoring missions for countries like Russia, Sri Lanka, Sudan, and Cambodia to keep an eye on ongoing rights issues there. For the first time since 2019, the Council passed a resolution led by African countries to fight racism, showing some progress despite remaining disagreements. They also agreed on resolutions related to economic inequality and the effects of climate change, such as rising sea levels.

**Impact** – These decisions are important because they show countries can work together to hold those who break human rights laws accountable. The new investigation in Afghanistan sends a clear message that serious crimes will not be ignored. Renewing monitoring missions helps protect vulnerable people by providing trusted information and support. The resolution on racism marks a rare moment of unity on a difficult topic. Tackling economic and climate issues also connects human rights to everyday problems many people face, especially in poorer countries.

**What's next step** – The new evidence-gathering body in Afghanistan will begin its investigations, which could lead to future legal actions against those responsible. The monitoring missions will continue their work, providing updates and reports. The Council and its members will likely keep discussing ways to address racism, inequality, and climate change, aiming to turn these resolutions into real changes on the ground.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN Human Rights Council has taken important new actions to investigate abuses, monitor rights worldwide, and address racism and inequality through international cooperation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Conseil des droits de l’homme de l’ONU renforce la protection des droits dans le monde
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Conseil des droits de l’homme des Nations Unies se réunit régulièrement pour traiter des problèmes graves liés aux droits humains dans le monde. Récemment, plusieurs pays ont montré moins d’intérêt à soutenir ces droits et à financer les actions nécessaires.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors de sa dernière session, le Conseil a décidé de créer un groupe indépendant chargé de recueillir des preuves sur les violations des droits en Afghanistan. Ce groupe enquêtera sur les crimes commis par les talibans, notamment contre les femmes et les filles. Le Conseil a aussi renouvelé les missions de surveillance dans des pays comme la Russie, le Sri Lanka, le Soudan et le Cambodge pour continuer à suivre les problèmes en cours. Pour la première fois depuis 2019, le Conseil a adopté une résolution menée par des pays africains pour lutter contre le racisme, ce qui montre un progrès malgré des désaccords. Il a aussi adopté des résolutions sur les inégalités économiques et les effets du changement climatique, comme la montée du niveau de la mer.

**Impact** – Ces décisions sont importantes car elles montrent que les pays peuvent collaborer pour tenir responsables ceux qui violent les droits humains. La nouvelle enquête en Afghanistan envoie un message clair que les crimes graves ne seront pas ignorés. Le renouvellement des missions de surveillance aide à protéger les personnes vulnérables en fournissant des informations fiables et du soutien. La résolution sur le racisme marque un moment rare d’unité sur un sujet difficile. Aborder les questions économiques et climatiques relie les droits humains aux problèmes quotidiens, surtout dans les pays pauvres.

**Prochaine étape** – Le nouveau groupe d’enquête en Afghanistan commencera son travail, ce qui pourrait mener à des actions judiciaires futures contre les responsables. Les missions de surveillance continueront leur suivi en fournissant des rapports. Le Conseil et ses membres continueront probablement à discuter des moyens de lutter contre le racisme, les inégalités et le changement climatique, pour transformer ces résolutions en actions concrètes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le Conseil des droits de l’homme de l’ONU a pris des mesures importantes pour enquêter sur les abus, surveiller les droits dans le monde et lutter contre le racisme et les inégalités grâce à la coopération internationale.
articles.personality_title_es: El Consejo de Derechos Humanos de la ONU da pasos firmes para proteger derechos en todo el mundo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Consejo de Derechos Humanos de las Naciones Unidas se reúne regularmente para tratar problemas graves relacionados con los derechos humanos en el mundo. Últimamente, algunos países han mostrado menos interés en apoyar estos derechos y en financiar el trabajo necesario.

**Qué pasó** – En su última sesión, el Consejo acordó crear un grupo independiente para recopilar pruebas sobre abusos de derechos humanos en Afganistán. Este grupo investigará los crímenes cometidos por los talibanes, especialmente contra mujeres y niñas. El Consejo también renovó las misiones de monitoreo en países como Rusia, Sri Lanka, Sudán y Camboya para seguir vigilando los problemas actuales. Por primera vez desde 2019, el Consejo aprobó una resolución liderada por países africanos para combatir el racismo, mostrando un progreso a pesar de desacuerdos. También aprobaron resoluciones sobre desigualdad económica y los efectos del cambio climático, como la subida del nivel del mar.

**Impacto** – Estas decisiones son importantes porque muestran que los países pueden trabajar juntos para responsabilizar a quienes violan los derechos humanos. La nueva investigación en Afganistán envía un mensaje claro de que los crímenes graves no serán ignorados. Renovar las misiones de monitoreo ayuda a proteger a personas vulnerables proporcionando información confiable y apoyo. La resolución sobre racismo marca un momento raro de unidad en un tema difícil. Abordar cuestiones económicas y climáticas conecta los derechos humanos con problemas cotidianos, especialmente en países pobres.

**Próximo paso** – El nuevo grupo de investigación en Afganistán comenzará su trabajo, lo que podría llevar a futuras acciones legales contra los responsables. Las misiones de monitoreo continuarán su labor brindando informes. El Consejo y sus miembros probablemente seguirán discutiendo formas de enfrentar el racismo, la desigualdad y el cambio climático para convertir estas resoluciones en acciones concretas.

**Resumen en una frase** – El Consejo de Derechos Humanos de la ONU ha tomado medidas importantes para investigar abusos, monitorear derechos en todo el mundo y abordar el racismo y la desigualdad mediante la cooperación internacional.

articles.title: Qatar: Baha’i Dignitary Acquitted
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Remy Rowhani
                    © Private.
          
    


  
(Beirut) – Qatari authorities have acquitted and released Remy Rowhani, chair of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha’is in Qatar, after months of arbitrary detention based solely on his religious identity, Human Rights Watch said today. Qatar should immediately end discrimination against Baha’is and provide effective remedy for those affected.Qatar’s court of appeal reversed Rowhani’s baseless conviction on September 30, 2025, court documents reviewed by Human Rights Watch show. Rowhani was sentenced to five years in prison by a lower court in August on charges based on the peaceful exercise of his rights to freedom of speech and religion. Rowhani was released on October 4, an informed source told Human Rights Watch. However, the prosecutor can appeal the decision within 60 days.“It is very good news that a Qatari court acquitted Remy Rowhani of all the baseless charges against him,” said Michael Page, deputy Middle East director at Human Rights Watch. “Qatari authorities should build on this positive development by ensuring that Baha’is no longer face religious discrimination by Qatari government institutions.”The Baha’i faith, founded in 19th-century Iran by Baha’u’llah, believes in the unity of all religions and people. The Qatari government has a longstanding record of discriminating against Baha’is in Qatar, with hundreds harmed by deportations, blacklisting, and administrative restrictions for no apparent reason other than individuals’ belonging to the Baha’i faith.Baha’is are also frequently discriminated against elsewhere in the region, including in Egypt and Yemen, and face persecution, a crime against humanity, by authorities in Iran.Qatari authorities arrested and detained Rowhani in April on charges claiming that he violated public order and social and religious Muslim values in Instagram and X accounts linked to him, the court documents say. Human Rights Watch reviewed the accounts and found that the posts are limited to celebrating Baha’i values and Qatari and Muslim holidays.The court denied Rowhani’s lawyer’s request to review the documents that outline the charges and evidence, and it did not allow him to defend his client during the first hearing, the informed source said.Qatar’s deputy attorney general appealed the sentence on September 7 seeking a harsher sentence, according to the appeal document, despite calls by rights groups, United Nations experts, and international media to end Qatar’s discriminatory treatment of Baha’is and release Rowhani.Human Rights Watch has documented Qatari discrimination against Baha’is, as have UN special rapporteurs on minority issues and freedom of religion or belief. Qatari authorities’ discriminatory treatment against Baha’is has resulted in the separation of families and the loss of employment and income, UN experts concluded.The authorities have also delayed the community’s attempts to reestablish an existing Baha’i cemetery and refused to accept marriage certificates issued by elected Baha’i institutions in Qatar, according to UN experts.“Rowhani’s release is a positive step, but Qatar needs to do more than release Rowhani to signal a genuine policy shift in its treatment of members of the Baha’i faith,” Page said.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Remy Rowhani © Private.

(Beirut) – Qatari authorities have acquitted and released Remy Rowhani, chair of the National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha’is in Qatar, after months of arbitrary detention based solely on his religious identity, Human Rights Watch said today. Qatar should immediately end discrimination against Baha’is and provide effective remedy for those affected.

Qatar’s court of appeal reversed Rowhani’s baseless conviction on September 30, 2025, court documents reviewed by Human Rights Watch show. Rowhani was sentenced to five years in prison by a lower court in August on charges based on the peaceful exercise of his rights to freedom of speech and religion. Rowhani was released on October 4, an informed source told Human Rights Watch. However, the prosecutor can appeal the decision within 60 days.

“It is very good news that a Qatari court acquitted Remy Rowhani of all the baseless charges against him,” said Michael Page, deputy Middle East director at Human Rights Watch. “Qatari authorities should build on this positive development by ensuring that Baha’is no longer face religious discrimination by Qatari government institutions.”

The Baha’i faith, founded in 19th-century Iran by Baha’u’llah, believes in the unity of all religions and people. The Qatari government has a longstanding record of discriminating against Baha’is in Qatar, with hundreds harmed by deportations, blacklisting, and administrative restrictions for no apparent reason other than individuals’ belonging to the Baha’i faith.

Baha’is are also frequently discriminated against elsewhere in the region, including in Egypt and Yemen, and face persecution, a crime against humanity, by authorities in Iran.

Qatari authorities arrested and detained Rowhani in April on charges claiming that he violated public order and social and religious Muslim values in Instagram and X accounts linked to him, the court documents say. Human Rights Watch reviewed the accounts and found that the posts are limited to celebrating Baha’i values and Qatari and Muslim holidays.

The court denied Rowhani’s lawyer’s request to review the documents that outline the charges and evidence, and it did not allow him to defend his client during the first hearing, the informed source said.

Qatar’s deputy attorney general appealed the sentence on September 7 seeking a harsher sentence, according to the appeal document, despite calls by rights groups, United Nations experts, and international media to end Qatar’s discriminatory treatment of Baha’is and release Rowhani.

Human Rights Watch has documented Qatari discrimination against Baha’is, as have UN special rapporteurs on minority issues and freedom of religion or belief. Qatari authorities’ discriminatory treatment against Baha’is has resulted in the separation of families and the loss of employment and income, UN experts concluded.

The authorities have also delayed the community’s attempts to reestablish an existing Baha’i cemetery and refused to accept marriage certificates issued by elected Baha’i institutions in Qatar, according to UN experts.

“Rowhani’s release is a positive step, but Qatar needs to do more than release Rowhani to signal a genuine policy shift in its treatment of members of the Baha’i faith,” Page said.
articles.reasoning: The article reports the acquittal and release of a religious minority leader wrongfully detained for his faith, marking a positive legal and human rights development with potential broader impact on religious freedom and anti-discrimination in Qatar. While the article highlights ongoing challenges, the acquittal represents a meaningful step forward in human rights for the Baha’i community in the region.
articles.personality_title: Qatar acquits Baha’i leader after wrongful detention
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Remy Rowhani, leader of the Baha’i community in Qatar, was held in prison for months because of his religious beliefs. The Baha’i faith is a religion that promotes unity among all people and was founded in 19th-century Iran. In Qatar and some nearby countries, Baha’is often face unfair treatment and discrimination.

**What happened** – On September 30, 2025, Qatar’s court of appeal cleared Rowhani of all charges that were based on his peaceful religious activities and speech. He had been sentenced to five years in prison in August but was released on October 4. It shows that courts can recognize when charges against religious minorities are unfair. However, the case also highlights ongoing problems like restrictions on Baha’i marriage certificates and community sites. Future actions may include allowing Baha’i institutions to operate freely and restoring community rights.

articles.title: At the Europe House, opportunities through the Erasmus  program for Bosnian students were presented
articles.summary: Europe House in Sarajevo hosted students at a presentation of the Erasmus+ program as part of the global ErasmusDays campaign, with the presence of EU Ambassador Luigi Soreca and Erasmus+ alumni who highlighted the importance of the program for education, exchange, and the European integration of youth in BiH.
articles.content:
Europe House in Sarajevo hosted students at a presentation of the Erasmus+ program as part of the global ErasmusDays campaign, with the presence of EU Ambassador Luigi Soreca and Erasmus+ alumni who highlighted the importance of the program for education, exchange, and the European integration of youth in BiH.

Sarajevo, (Fena) – Europe House in Sarajevo hosted students at an interactive presentation of the Erasmus+ program, one of the most successful programs of the European Union, as part of the broader ErasmusDays campaign taking place worldwide to raise awareness of the opportunities offered by this initiative.

Students were joined by the head of the European Union Delegation to Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU Special Representative in BiH, Ambassador Luigi Soreca, as well as numerous Erasmus+ alumni who shared their unique experiences.

During his welcoming speech, Ambassador Soreca emphasized the importance of mobility and youth exchange programs, as well as their impact on empowering new generations to be actively involved in the process of European integration – it was announced by the EU Delegation in BiH.

– Erasmus+ is a truly European experience – one that transcends borders and languages, representing the true spirit of European unity and cooperation. For many, Erasmus+ is an experience that changes life perceptions – an opportunity to study abroad, meet new people, and create new understandings. It is important to encourage and motivate others to apply and take advantage of this opportunity. Erasmus+ is a program that helps you step out of your comfort zone, grow, learn, understand, and support Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path to membership in our Union – said the ambassador.

Interested students had the opportunity to learn more about the program from the staff of the University of Sarajevo, which coordinates the process, as well as to hear personal mobility experiences from former Erasmus+ students who highlighted how the exchange supported their academic and career goals.

Considering the encouraging increase in the number of applications from students in BiH, as well as the rise in the number of international students coming to Bosnia and Herzegovina under the mobility program, participants agreed that mobility opportunities should be promoted more and presented to students across the country.

As part of the ErasmusDays activities, Europe House, in collaboration with the University of Tuzla, will organize an Info Day on October 16 to share opportunities with students from the Tuzla region.

Most Erasmus students happily emphasize that the exchange enriched their lives and opened new opportunities.

Sergej Mačar, a graphic designer and photographer born in Sarajevo, is one of them. Mačar’s internationally awarded exhibition “Sur,” inspired by his experience during the Erasmus exchange, was opened at Europe House in the presence of the Deputy Ambassador of Spain to BiH, Sol Cabanas.

– I am very proud that Spain is among the favorite destinations for Erasmus+ students from Bosnia and Herzegovina. I myself was on an Erasmus exchange, and it is an experience I carry with me even today. It is more than just an academic exchange; this experience truly changes lives, connects people across the continent, and strengthens European identity – said Cabanas. (14.10.)
